meta.title: Verbal & Non Verbal Reasoning MCQs
meta.description: Practice questions on Data Tables, Bar Graphs, Line Graphs, Pie Charts, and more.
meta.keywords: data interpretation, mcqs, quiz, data tables, bar graphs, line graphs, pie charts

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Study 2. Job 3. Examination 4. Earn 5. Apply
questions.ex: The correct sequence is: Study (1) -> Examination (3) -> Apply (5) -> Job (2) -> Earn (4).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Plant 2. Food 3. Seed 4. Leaf 5. Flower
questions.ex: The correct sequence is: Seed (3) -> Plant (1) -> Leaf (4) -> Flower (5) -> Food (2).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Birth 2. Death 3. Funeral 4. Marriage 5. Education
questions.ex: The correct sequence representing stages of life is: Birth (1) -> Education (5) -> Marriage (4) -> Death (2) -> Funeral (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Rain 2. Vaporization 3. Clouds 4. Condensation 5. Water
questions.ex: The correct sequence of the water cycle is: Water (5) -> Vaporization (2) -> Clouds (3) -> Condensation (4) -> Rain (1).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Letter 2. Word 3. Sentence 4. Phrase 5. Paragraph
questions.ex: The correct sequence from smallest to largest unit of text is: Letter (1) -> Word (2) -> Phrase (4) -> Sentence (3) -> Paragraph (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Infant 2. Adult 3. Adolescent 4. Child 5. Old age
questions.ex: The correct sequence of human life stages is: Infant (1) -> Child (4) -> Adolescent (3) -> Adult (2) -> Old age (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Weaving 2. Cotton 3. Cloth 4. Thread
questions.ex: The correct sequence of cloth production is: Cotton (2) -> Thread (4) -> Weaving (1) -> Cloth (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Site 2. Plan 3. Rent 4. Money 5. Building 6. Construction
questions.ex: A logical sequence for acquiring a building could be: Money (4) -> Site (1) -> Plan (2) -> Construction (6) -> Building (5) -> Rent (3) (if renting out). Or if renting for oneself, Money -> Plan -> Site -> Construction -> Building -> Occupy (Rent implies payment). Option A is most logical for building and then renting out.

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Probation 2. Interview 3. Selection 4. Appointment 5. Advertisement 6. Application
questions.ex: The correct sequence of a recruitment process is: Advertisement (5) -> Application (6) -> Interview (2) -> Selection (3) -> Appointment (4) -> Probation (1).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Income 2. Status 3. Education 4. Well-being 5. Job
questions.ex: A common progression is: Education (3) -> Job (5) -> Income (1) -> Status (2) -> Well-being (4).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Tree 2. Wood 3. Paper 4. Book 5. Pulp
questions.ex: The process of making a book from a tree: Tree (1) -> Wood (2) -> Pulp (5) -> Paper (3) -> Book (4).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Diagnosis 2. Doctor 3. Sickness 4. Treatment 5. Recovery
questions.ex: The typical medical process: Sickness (3) -> Doctor (2) -> Diagnosis (1) -> Treatment (4) -> Recovery (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Gold 2. Iron 3. Sand 4. Platinum 5. Diamond
questions.ex: Arranging by approximate value/rarity from less to more valuable: Sand (3) -> Iron (2) -> Gold (1) -> Diamond (5) -> Platinum (4). (Note: Diamond and Platinum values can vary, but this is a common perception).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Reading 2. Composing 3. Writing 4. Printing
questions.ex: The process of creating and consuming written material: Composing (2) -> Writing (3) -> Printing (4) -> Reading (1).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Country 2. District 3. State 4. Village 5. Continent
questions.ex: Arranging geographical units from smallest to largest: Village (4) -> District (2) -> State (3) -> Country (1) -> Continent (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Shoulder 2. Wrist 3. Elbow 4. Palm 5. Finger
questions.ex: Sequence of parts of the arm from top to bottom: Shoulder (1) -> Elbow (3) -> Wrist (2) -> Palm (4) -> Finger (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Foundation 2. Walls 3. Roof 4. Plastering 5. Painting
questions.ex: Sequence of house construction: Foundation (1) -> Walls (2) -> Roof (3) -> Plastering (4) -> Painting (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Dough 2. Flour 3. Bread 4. Baking 5. Wheat
questions.ex: Process of making bread: Wheat (5) -> Flour (2) -> Dough (1) -> Baking (4) -> Bread (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Result 2. Campaign 3. OATH 4. Polling 5. Nominations
questions.ex: Sequence of an election process: Nominations (5) -> Campaign (2) -> Polling (4) -> Result (1) -> Oath (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Yarn 2. Silkworm 3. Saree 4. Silk 5. Cloth
questions.ex: Process of making a silk saree: Silkworm (2) -> Silk (4) -> Yarn (1) -> Cloth (5) -> Saree (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Cutting 2. Dish 3. Vegetable 4. Cooking 5. Market
questions.ex: Process of preparing a dish: Market (5) -> Vegetable (3) -> Cutting (1) -> Cooking (4) -> Dish (2).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Frog 2. Eagle 3. Grasshopper 4. Snake 5. Grass
questions.ex: A food chain sequence: Grass (5) -> Grasshopper (3) -> Frog (1) -> Snake (4) -> Eagle (2).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Presentation 2. Recommendation 3. Arrival 4. Discussion 5. Introduction
questions.ex: Sequence of events in a formal meeting or presentation: Arrival (3) -> Introduction (5) -> Presentation (1) -> Discussion (4) -> Recommendation (2).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Index 2. Contents 3. Title 4. Chapters 5. Introduction
questions.ex: Typical order of sections in a book: Title (3) -> Introduction (5) -> Contents (2) -> Chapters (4) -> Index (1).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Poverty 2. Population 3. Death 4. Unemployment 5. Disease
questions.ex: A possible causal sequence of societal problems: Population (2) -> Unemployment (4) -> Poverty (1) -> Disease (5) -> Death (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Mother 2. Child 3. Milk 4. Cry 5. Smile
questions.ex: A common interaction: Child (2) -> Cry (4) -> Mother (1) -> Milk (3) -> Smile (5).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. College 2. Child 3. Salary 4. School 5. Employment
questions.ex: Life progression related to education and career: Child (2) -> School (4) -> College (1) -> Employment (5) -> Salary (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Curd 2. Grass 3. Butter 4. Milk 5. Cow
questions.ex: Production of dairy products: Grass (2) -> Cow (5) -> Milk (4) -> Curd (1) -> Butter (3).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Travel 2. Destination 3. Payment 4. Berth/Seat reservation 5. Availability of berth/seat for reservation
questions.ex: Process of booking travel: Destination (2) -> Availability of berth/seat for reservation (5) -> Berth/Seat reservation (4) -> Payment (3) -> Travel (1).

questions.q: Arrange the following words in a meaningful sequence: 1. Key 2. Door 3. Lock 4. Room 5. Switch on light
questions.ex: Sequence of entering a room: Key (1) -> Lock (3) -> Door (2) -> Room (4) -> Switch on light (5).

questions.q: Assertion (A): The sun rises in the east. Reason (R): The earth rotates from west to east.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The Earth's rotation from west to east causes the apparent movement of the sun from east to west, hence the sun rises in the east. So, R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Diamond is very hard. Reason (R): Diamond is made of carbon atoms.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Diamond is indeed very hard, and it is made of carbon atoms. However, the reason for its hardness is its specific tetrahedral crystal structure, not just that it's made of carbon (graphite is also carbon but is soft). So, R is true but not the complete or direct explanation for A's hardness in this context.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Boiling point of water increases with increase in pressure. Reason (R): Water boils when its vapor pressure equals the external pressure.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Water boils when its saturated vapor pressure equals the external (atmospheric) pressure. If the external pressure is increased, a higher temperature is needed for the vapor pressure to reach this new external pressure, thus the boiling point increases. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): We feel cooler on a windy day than on a calm day when the temperature is the same. Reason (R): Wind increases the rate of evaporation of sweat from our body.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Evaporation causes cooling. Wind carries away the moist air near the skin, allowing more sweat to evaporate, thus leading to a greater cooling effect. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Iron objects rust in moist air. Reason (R): Rusting is a process of oxidation.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Iron reacts with oxygen and water (moist air) to form hydrated iron(III) oxide, which is rust. This chemical reaction is an oxidation process. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): A person feels weightlessness in a satellite. Reason (R): The satellite is not acted upon by gravity.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: A person feels weightlessness in an orbiting satellite because both the satellite and the person are in a constant state of free fall towards the Earth. Gravity is very much acting on the satellite; it's what keeps it in orbit. So, A is true, but R is false.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Sound waves cannot travel through vacuum. Reason (R): Sound waves are longitudinal waves.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Sound waves require a medium (like air, water, solids) to propagate because they are vibrations of particles in the medium. Vacuum has no particles, so sound cannot travel. Sound waves are indeed longitudinal waves (in fluids and gases), but this property itself isn't why they can't travel in vacuum; it's the need for a medium. So, both A and R are true, but R is not the direct explanation for A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Plants are green in color. Reason (R): Plants contain a pigment called chlorophyll.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Chlorophyll is the green pigment in plants that absorbs light for photosynthesis. It reflects green light, which is why plants appear green. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): A ship made of iron floats in water whereas an iron nail sinks. Reason (R): The density of iron is less than the density of water.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: A ship floats because its overall shape displaces a large volume of water, making its average density (mass of ship / volume displaced) less than water. An iron nail sinks because iron's density is greater than water's density. So, A is true, but R (The density of iron is less than the density of water) is false.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Cooking is faster in a pressure cooker. Reason (R): The high pressure in the cooker raises the boiling point of water.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: In a pressure cooker, the trapped steam increases the pressure, which in turn raises the boiling point of water. Food cooks faster at this higher temperature. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Deforestation leads to soil erosion. Reason (R): Tree roots bind the soil particles together.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Tree roots hold the soil together, preventing it from being easily washed or blown away. When trees are removed (deforestation), the soil becomes loose and prone to erosion. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Sky appears blue. Reason (R): Blue light is scattered more than other colors by air molecules.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: This phenomenon is called Rayleigh scattering. Air molecules scatter shorter wavelengths of light (like blue and violet) more effectively than longer wavelengths (like red). Our eyes are more sensitive to blue, so the sky appears blue. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): It is difficult to walk on a slippery surface. Reason (R): Slippery surfaces have very low friction.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: We need friction to push against the ground to walk. Slippery surfaces offer very little friction, making it hard to get a grip and move forward. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Vaccines prevent diseases. Reason (R): Vaccines kill all disease-causing microorganisms in the body.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Vaccines work by introducing a harmless form of a pathogen (or its components) to stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies and memory cells. This prepares the body to fight off future infections by that specific pathogen. Vaccines don't typically 'kill all' microorganisms; they enable the immune system. So, A is true, but R is false.

questions.q: Assertion (A): We wear light-colored clothes in summer. Reason (R): Light colors are good reflectors of heat.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Light-colored surfaces reflect most of the light (and heat) that falls on them, while dark colors absorb more. Wearing light colors in summer helps to keep us cool by reflecting solar radiation. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Earthquakes are caused by the movement of tectonic plates. Reason (R): The Earth's crust is made up of several large and small plates.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The Earth's lithosphere is divided into tectonic plates that are constantly moving. Earthquakes occur when these plates slip past each other, releasing energy. R provides the context for A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): A convex mirror is used as a rear-view mirror in vehicles. Reason (R): Convex mirrors form virtual, erect, and diminished images.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Convex mirrors provide a wider field of view and always form virtual, erect, and smaller images of objects. This allows drivers to see a larger area behind them. R correctly explains why A is done.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas. Reason (R): Carbon dioxide traps heat in the Earth's atmosphere.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Greenhouse gases, like carbon dioxide, absorb and emit infrared radiation (heat), trapping it in the atmosphere and contributing to the greenhouse effect and global warming. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Metals are good conductors of electricity. Reason (R): Metals have free electrons.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The presence of delocalized or free electrons in metals allows them to move easily under an electric field, carrying charge and thus conducting electricity. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): The moon has no atmosphere. Reason (R): The escape velocity on the moon is very low.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The escape velocity is the minimum speed needed for an object (like a gas molecule) to escape from the gravitational influence of a celestial body. The moon's gravity is weak, so its escape velocity is low. Gas molecules, if present, would easily escape into space, hence it has no significant atmosphere. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Osmosis is the movement of water molecules from a region of higher concentration to lower concentration. Reason (R): Osmosis occurs through a semipermeable membrane.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Osmosis is specifically the movement of solvent (usually water) molecules across a selectively permeable membrane from a region of higher solvent (lower solute) concentration to a region of lower solvent (higher solute) concentration. While A is generally true in terms of water potential, R is a necessary condition for osmosis. Both are true, but R is a defining characteristic rather than the sole explanation of the direction of movement described in A (which is driven by differences in water potential/solute concentration).

questions.q: Assertion (A): A rainbow is formed due to dispersion of sunlight by raindrops. Reason (R): Different colors of light bend by different amounts when passing through a prism.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Raindrops act like tiny prisms. When sunlight enters a raindrop, it is refracted and dispersed into its constituent colors because each color (wavelength) is refracted at a slightly different angle. This separation of colors, along with internal reflection, leads to the formation of a rainbow. R explains the dispersion part of A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Bats can fly in the dark. Reason (R): Bats emit ultrasonic waves.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Bats use echolocation. They emit high-frequency sound waves (ultrasonic) and listen for the echoes bouncing off objects. This allows them to navigate and find prey in complete darkness. R correctly explains how A is possible.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Ice floats on water. Reason (R): Ice is denser than water.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Ice floats on water because it is less dense than liquid water. This is an unusual property, as most substances are denser in their solid state. So, A is true, but R is false.

questions.q: Assertion (A): When lightning strikes, the sound is heard a little after the flash is seen. Reason (R): The speed of light is much greater than the speed of sound.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Light travels at approximately 3 x 10^8 m/s, while sound travels much slower in air (around 343 m/s at room temperature). Therefore, the light from the flash reaches us almost instantaneously, while the sound (thunder) takes longer. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Food gets cooked faster at high altitudes. Reason (R): Atmospheric pressure is lower at high altitudes.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: At high altitudes, the atmospheric pressure is lower. This causes water to boil at a lower temperature. Since food cooks due to the heat from boiling water, a lower boiling temperature means food cooks slower, not faster. So, A is false, but R is true.

questions.q: Assertion (A): A compass needle points towards the geographic North-South direction. Reason (R): The Earth behaves as a magnet with its magnetic poles located near its geographic poles.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The Earth has a magnetic field, and a compass needle (which is a small magnet) aligns itself with this field, pointing towards the Earth's magnetic north pole (which is near the geographic North Pole). R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): It is dangerous to stand under a tree during a thunderstorm. Reason (R): Trees attract lightning.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Lightning tends to strike taller objects, and trees are often the tallest objects in an open area. Standing under a tree increases the risk of being struck by lightning or by a side flash. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Nuclear fusion is the source of the Sun's energy. Reason (R): In nuclear fusion, lighter nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus, releasing energy.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: The Sun's energy is produced by nuclear fusion reactions in its core, primarily converting hydrogen into helium. This process involves lighter atomic nuclei fusing to form a heavier nucleus, with a release of a tremendous amount of energy. R correctly describes the process that explains A.

questions.q: Assertion (A): Clothes dry faster on a hot and windy day. Reason (R): The rate of evaporation increases with temperature and wind speed.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.
questions.ex: Higher temperatures provide more energy for water molecules to evaporate, and wind carries away the moist air, allowing more evaporation to occur. Both factors increase the rate of evaporation, causing clothes to dry faster. R correctly explains A.

questions.q: Statement I: The government has increased the prices of petrol and diesel. Statement II: The sale of electric vehicles has increased significantly in the last quarter.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Increased fuel prices (Statement I) would likely make people consider alternatives like electric vehicles, leading to increased sales (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: There has been a significant drop in the water level of all the lakes supplying water to the city. Statement II: The municipal corporation has appealed to all the citizens to reduce their water consumption by 20%.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A drop in water levels (Statement I) is a problem that would necessitate an appeal for reduced consumption (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: Many students were caught using unfair means during the final examination. Statement II: The school authority has decided to debar all these students from appearing in examinations for the next three years.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Students using unfair means (Statement I) is an offense that would lead to disciplinary action like debarment (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The local cooperative credit society has decided to stop advancing loans to farmers for a temporary period. Statement II: A large number of credit society members have withdrawn a major part of their deposits from the society.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: If many members withdraw their deposits (Statement II), the society would face a shortage of funds, forcing it to stop advancing loans (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The prices of vegetables have increased considerably during the past few weeks. Statement II: The transport operators have gone on an indefinite strike protesting against the hike in diesel prices.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A transport strike (Statement II) would disrupt the supply of vegetables to the market, leading to a shortage and consequently an increase in prices (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The university has decided to conduct all terminal examinations online this year. Statement II: There has been a consistent rise in COVID-19 cases in the region.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A rise in COVID-19 cases (Statement II) would make physical examinations risky, prompting the university to conduct them online (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The company has recently announced several new welfare schemes for its employees. Statement II: The company has achieved record profits in the last financial year.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Achieving record profits (Statement II) would provide the company with the resources and motivation to introduce new welfare schemes for its employees (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The meteorological department has issued a warning about heavy rainfall in the next 48 hours. Statement II: Many people have postponed their travel plans.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A warning about heavy rainfall (Statement I) would likely cause people to postpone their travel plans (Statement II) to avoid inconvenience or danger. Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The literacy rate in the district has been increasing for the last four years. Statement II: The district administration has conducted an extensive awareness campaign for education.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: An extensive awareness campaign for education (Statement II) would lead to an increase in the literacy rate (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The performance of most students in the final exams of Class X was excellent. Statement II: Many teachers of Class X left the school before the final exams.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Excellent student performance (Statement I) and teachers leaving (Statement II) are unlikely to be directly related as cause and effect. They are more likely effects of different, independent causes (e.g., good teaching methods for I, better job opportunities for II).

questions.q: Statement I: The city witnessed heavy showers for three consecutive days. Statement II: All schools in the city were closed for two days.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Heavy showers (Statement I) can lead to waterlogging and traffic disruptions, prompting authorities to close schools (Statement II) for safety. Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The airline has suspended all its flights to the country for a week. Statement II: The political situation in the country has deteriorated sharply.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A deteriorating political situation (Statement II) can create safety concerns and operational difficulties, leading airlines to suspend flights (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The price of gold has been increasing steadily for the past few months. Statement II: Many people are investing in gold as a safe asset.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Both increasing gold prices (Statement I) and people investing in gold (Statement II) could be effects of a common cause, such as economic uncertainty or inflation, which makes gold an attractive investment and drives up its demand and price.

questions.q: Statement I: The company's stock price fell sharply after the quarterly results were announced. Statement II: The company reported a significant loss in the last quarter.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Reporting a significant loss (Statement II) is bad news for a company and would typically cause its stock price to fall (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The number of road accidents has increased in the city. Statement II: The city traffic police have launched a special drive to check for drunk driving.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: An increase in road accidents (Statement I) would prompt the traffic police to take measures like a special drive against drunk driving (Statement II) to address the problem. Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The government has banned the import of certain electronic goods. Statement II: The domestic production of similar electronic goods has increased.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Banning imports (Statement I) creates a gap in the market that domestic producers can fill, leading to increased domestic production (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The quality of air in the city has improved significantly. Statement II: The government has implemented strict emission norms for vehicles and industries.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Implementing strict emission norms (Statement II) would reduce pollution, leading to an improvement in air quality (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: Many farmers are opting for organic farming methods. Statement II: There is a growing demand for organic food products in the market.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A growing demand for organic products (Statement II) would incentivize farmers to adopt organic farming methods (Statement I) to cater to this demand. Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The incidence of water-borne diseases has increased in the area. Statement II: The local civic body has failed to provide safe drinking water.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Failure to provide safe drinking water (Statement II) can lead to contamination and an increase in water-borne diseases (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The sales of winter clothing have gone up. Statement II: The temperature has dropped significantly in the last few days.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A significant drop in temperature (Statement II) would lead people to buy more winter clothing (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The police resorted to lathi-charge to disperse the unlawful gathering of a large number of people. Statement II: The citizens' forum called a general strike in protest against the police atrocities.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Police lathi-charge (Statement I), perceived as an atrocity, would likely lead to protests like a general strike (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The standard of living of people in the city has improved. Statement II: Many new industries have been set up in the city in the last five years.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Setting up new industries (Statement II) creates employment and economic growth, which in turn improves the standard of living (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The government has decided to increase the import duty on sugar. Statement II: The price of sugar in the domestic market has increased in the recent past.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: An increase in domestic sugar prices (Statement II) might prompt the government to increase import duty (Statement I) to protect local producers. Conversely, an increase in import duty (Statement I) could also lead to higher domestic prices (Statement II). However, it's also possible both are effects of a common cause like poor domestic harvest or global price rise. Option 4 (effects of some common cause) or even I is cause and II is effect, or II is cause and I is effect are plausible. Given the options, if domestic prices are already high (II), the government might increase import duty (I) to curb cheap imports or raise revenue. Or, if import duty is increased (I), domestic prices (II) will likely rise. Let's consider if II (high domestic price) is a reason for I (increase import duty). This is less direct. More likely, if import duty (I) is increased, it makes imported sugar costlier, allowing domestic prices (II) to rise or stay high. So I could be a cause for II. However, if domestic prices (II) are already high due to, say, low production, the government might increase import duty (I) to protect farmers, but this would further increase prices. A common cause like 'government policy to support domestic sugar industry' could lead to both. Let's re-evaluate. If domestic prices (II) are high, the government might increase import duty (I) to discourage imports and protect local producers, or to raise revenue. This makes II a cause for I. Alternatively, if the government increases import duty (I), it makes imported sugar more expensive, which can lead to an increase in domestic sugar prices (II). This makes I a cause for II. If both are plausible, consider 'effects of some common cause'. A poor domestic harvest (common cause) could lead to high domestic prices (II) AND the government increasing import duty (I) to manage the situation or protect remaining farmers. This seems like a strong possibility for 'common cause'.

questions.q: Statement I: The rate of inflation has increased in the country. Statement II: The central bank has increased the interest rates.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Increased inflation (Statement I) is a problem that central banks typically address by increasing interest rates (Statement II) to curb spending and control prices. Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: There is a shortage of skilled labor in the IT sector. Statement II: Many IT companies are offering attractive salary packages and benefits.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A shortage of skilled labor (Statement I) creates competition among companies to attract and retain talent, leading them to offer attractive packages (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The forest department has launched a massive tree plantation drive. Statement II: The instances of landslides in the hilly areas have reduced.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A massive tree plantation drive (Statement I) helps in soil conservation and stabilization of slopes, which in turn can lead to a reduction in landslides (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The number of tourists visiting the hill station has declined sharply. Statement II: There have been several reports of unhygienic conditions and poor civic amenities in the hill station.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Reports of unhygienic conditions and poor amenities (Statement II) would deter tourists, leading to a decline in their numbers (Statement I). Thus, II is the cause and I is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The government has announced a new policy to promote renewable energy sources. Statement II: The country's dependence on fossil fuels has decreased.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A new policy promoting renewable energy (Statement I) would lead to increased use of renewables and consequently a decrease in dependence on fossil fuels (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The average global temperature has been rising. Statement II: Many glaciers are melting at an accelerated rate.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: Rising global temperatures (Statement I) cause glaciers to melt faster (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

questions.q: Statement I: The company launched a new advertising campaign. Statement II: The sales of the company's products increased significantly.
options: Statement I is the cause and Statement II is its effect.
Statement II is the cause and Statement I is its effect.
Both the statements I and II are independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of independent causes.
Both the statements I and II are effects of some common cause.
questions.ex: A new advertising campaign (Statement I) is intended to boost sales, and if successful, would lead to increased sales (Statement II). Thus, I is the cause and II is its effect.

subcategories.title: Verification of Truth of the Statement

questions.q: The sun rises in the west.
options: True
False
Cannot say
Partially True
questions.ex: The sun always rises in the east. Therefore, the statement is false.

questions.q: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius at sea level.
options: True
False
Depends on the purity of water
Depends on the container
questions.ex: This is a scientifically established fact. Water boils at 100°C (212°F) at standard atmospheric pressure (sea level).

questions.q: A week has eight days.
options: True
False
Sometimes
In some cultures
questions.ex: A standard week universally consists of seven days.

questions.q: Lions are herbivorous animals.
options: True
False
Only young lions
If no other food is available
questions.ex: Lions are carnivores, meaning they primarily eat meat.

questions.q: The capital of France is Berlin.
options: True
False
It used to be
Berlin is the capital of Germany
questions.ex: The capital of France is Paris. Berlin is the capital of Germany.

questions.q: Humans need oxygen to survive.
options: True
False
Only at high altitudes
Only when sleeping
questions.ex: Oxygen is essential for cellular respiration in humans and most other living organisms.

questions.q: The Earth is flat.
options: True
False
Appears flat from the ground
Some ancient texts say so
questions.ex: Scientific evidence overwhelmingly proves that the Earth is an oblate spheroid (a slightly flattened sphere).

questions.q: February always has 29 days.
options: True
False
Only in a leap year
Only in a common year
questions.ex: February has 29 days only in a leap year, which occurs every four years. In common years, it has 28 days.

questions.q: Trees produce carbon dioxide and absorb oxygen.
options: True
False
Only at night
Only certain types of trees
questions.ex: Trees, through photosynthesis, absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen during the day. They respire (like animals) by taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide, but the net effect during daylight is oxygen production.

questions.q: The Pacific Ocean is the smallest ocean in the world.
options: True
False
It is the largest
It is the second smallest
questions.ex: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest of Earth's oceanic divisions.

questions.q: A triangle has four sides.
options: True
False
If it's a special triangle
A quadrilateral has four sides
questions.ex: A triangle is a polygon with three edges and three vertices. A quadrilateral has four sides.

questions.q: Mount Everest is the highest mountain in the world.
options: True
False
K2 is higher
Depends on how it's measured
questions.ex: Mount Everest, with an elevation of 8,848.86 meters (29,031.7 feet) above sea level, is recognized as the Earth's highest mountain.

questions.q: Spiders are insects.
options: True
False
They are arachnids
Some species are
questions.ex: Spiders belong to the class Arachnida, not Insecta. Insects have six legs and three body parts, while spiders have eight legs and two body parts.

questions.q: The currency of Japan is the Dollar.
options: True
False
It is the Yen
It used to be the Dollar
questions.ex: The official currency of Japan is the Yen (JPY).

questions.q: Penguins can fly.
options: True
False
They are flightless birds
Only for short distances
questions.ex: Penguins are a group of aquatic, flightless birds. Their wings have evolved into flippers, making them excellent swimmers.

questions.q: The Great Wall of China is visible from the Moon with the naked eye.
options: True
False
It's a common misconception
Only with a telescope
questions.ex: This is a popular myth. The Great Wall is not visible from the Moon without aid, and even from low Earth orbit, it is difficult to see with the naked eye.

questions.q: Diamond is the hardest known natural substance.
options: True
False
Graphene is harder
Steel is harder
questions.ex: Diamond has the highest hardness and thermal conductivity of any natural material, used in cutting and polishing tools.

questions.q: The Amazon River is the longest river in the world.
options: True
False
The Nile is longer
It depends on the measurement criteria
questions.ex: While historically the Nile was considered longer, recent studies and measurements suggest the Amazon is longer, or at least comparable, depending on the definition of its source and mouth. For general knowledge, it's often cited as the longest or largest by volume.

questions.q: A decade consists of 12 years.
options: True
False
It is 10 years
A dozen is 12
questions.ex: A decade is a period of 10 years. A dozen refers to a group of 12.

questions.q: Mars is known as the Red Planet.
options: True
False
Jupiter is the Red Planet
Venus is the Red Planet
questions.ex: Mars is often called the 'Red Planet' because the iron oxide prevalent on its surface gives it a reddish appearance.

questions.q: Sound travels faster than light.
options: True
False
Light travels faster
They travel at the same speed
questions.ex: Light travels significantly faster than sound. The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second, while the speed of sound in air is about 343 meters per second.

questions.q: The primary colors are red, yellow, and blue.
options: True
False
In additive color models (light)
In subtractive color models (pigment)
questions.ex: In traditional color theory (subtractive color model, like pigments), red, yellow, and blue are considered the primary colors because they cannot be created by mixing other colors and can be mixed to create a range of other colors.

questions.q: Sharks are mammals.
options: True
False
They are fish
Some types are mammals
questions.ex: Sharks are a type of fish, specifically cartilaginous fish (Chondrichthyes). Mammals are warm-blooded vertebrates that nurse their young.

questions.q: The human body has 206 bones on average.
options: True
False
Babies have more
Adults have fewer
questions.ex: An adult human skeleton typically consists of 206 bones. Babies are born with more bones (around 270), some of which fuse together as they grow.

questions.q: Australia is both a country and a continent.
options: True
False
It is only a country
It is only a continent
questions.ex: Australia is unique in that it is the only landmass that is simultaneously a country, a continent, and an island.

questions.q: The freezing point of water is 32 degrees Celsius.
options: True
False
It is 0 degrees Celsius
It is 32 degrees Fahrenheit
questions.ex: The freezing point of water is 0 degrees Celsius or 32 degrees Fahrenheit.

questions.q: All birds can fly.
options: True
False
Some birds are flightless
Only young birds cannot fly
questions.ex: Not all birds can fly. Examples of flightless birds include penguins, ostriches, emus, and kiwis.

questions.q: The chemical symbol for gold is Ag.
options: True
False
It is Au
Ag is for Silver
questions.ex: The chemical symbol for gold is Au (from the Latin word 'aurum'). Ag is the chemical symbol for silver (from the Latin word 'argentum').

questions.q: A vegetarian eats meat.
options: True
False
Only fish
Occasionally
questions.ex: A vegetarian is a person who does not eat meat or fish, and sometimes other animal products.

questions.q: The moon orbits the Sun directly.
options: True
False
It orbits the Earth
The Earth orbits the Moon
questions.ex: The Moon is a natural satellite of the Earth and orbits the Earth. The Earth, along with the Moon, orbits the Sun.

questions.q: You are on your way to an important meeting and witness a road accident. The victim is injured and needs help. What would you do?
options: Ignore it and rush to your meeting as it's very important.
Stop, call emergency services, provide first aid if you can, and then inform your office about the delay.
Ask someone else at the scene to help and proceed to your meeting.
Take a picture and post it on social media to raise awareness.
questions.ex: A responsible citizen prioritizes saving a life or helping an injured person. Informing the office about a genuine delay is understandable.

questions.q: You find a wallet full of money and identification cards on a park bench. What is your course of action?
options: Take the money and leave the wallet.
Look for the owner's contact information and try to return it directly.
Leave the wallet where you found it, hoping the owner returns.
Deposit it at the nearest police station.
questions.ex: The most ethical and practical approach is to deposit the wallet with the police, who can officially find the owner. While trying to contact directly is good, it might not always be feasible or safe.

questions.q: During an examination, you see your close friend cheating. What would you do?
options: Ignore it, as it's your friend's matter.
Secretly signal your friend to stop.
Inform the invigilator about the cheating.
Help your friend by showing your answers.
questions.ex: Maintaining academic integrity is important. Informing the invigilator is the correct action, even if it involves a friend.

questions.q: You are in a crowded bus and see someone pickpocketing another passenger. What would you do?
options: Shout to alert the victim and other passengers.
Quietly confront the pickpocket yourself.
Ignore it to avoid personal risk.
Get off the bus at the next stop.
questions.ex: Raising an alarm helps to potentially stop the theft and alert others, including the victim. Direct confrontation can be risky.

questions.q: Your boss asks you to do something that you know is unethical. How would you react?
options: Do it without question to keep your job.
Politely refuse and explain your ethical concerns.
Do it but complain to your colleagues later.
Report your boss to higher authorities immediately.
questions.ex: It's important to maintain ethical standards. Politely refusing and explaining concerns is the first appropriate step. Escalation might be needed if the issue persists.

questions.q: You are leading a team project, and two team members are constantly arguing and not cooperating, affecting the project's progress. What should you do?
options: Take sides with the member you think is right.
Report them to your superior.
Arrange a meeting with them to mediate and find a resolution.
Ignore their conflict and hope it resolves itself.
questions.ex: As a leader, your role is to facilitate teamwork. Mediation is the first step to resolve conflict and get the project back on track.

questions.q: You accidentally damage a borrowed item from a friend. What would you do?
options: Hide the damage and return it quietly.
Inform your friend immediately, apologize, and offer to repair or replace it.
Blame someone else for the damage.
Avoid your friend until they forget about it.
questions.ex: Honesty and taking responsibility are key in friendships. Informing, apologizing, and offering to rectify the damage is the right approach.

questions.q: You are offered a bribe to speed up an official process. What is your reaction?
options: Accept it, as it's a common practice.
Politely refuse the bribe and state that you will follow the due process.
Accept it and then report the person offering it.
Negotiate for a higher amount.
questions.ex: Accepting a bribe is illegal and unethical. Refusing firmly and adhering to proper procedures is the correct response.

questions.q: You are waiting in a long queue, and someone tries to cut in front of you. How do you respond?
options: Let them cut in to avoid confrontation.
Politely tell them there is a queue and they should go to the back.
Start an argument with them loudly.
Complain to the staff immediately.
questions.ex: Assertively but politely addressing the person is the most appropriate first step. Escalating to staff can be a second step if needed.

questions.q: You discover a major fire in your apartment building. What is your immediate action?
options: Try to put out the fire yourself with available resources.
Immediately alert other residents and call the fire department, then evacuate.
Run out of the building without alerting anyone.
Go back to your apartment to save your valuables.
questions.ex: Safety is paramount. Alerting others and emergency services, then evacuating, is the priority. Saving valuables should not risk lives.

questions.q: You are at a party and your friend who drove you there has had too much to drink. They insist on driving back. What do you do?
options: Let them drive but stay awake to monitor them.
Try to persuade them not to drive and suggest alternatives like a taxi or staying over.
Drive their car yourself if you are sober and licensed.
Both b and c are good options depending on the situation.
questions.ex: Preventing drunk driving is crucial. Persuading them not to drive and offering alternatives, or driving for them if possible, are responsible actions.

questions.q: You receive an email asking for your bank account details from an unknown source, promising a large sum of money. What should you do?
options: Reply with your bank details to claim the money.
Delete the email immediately and mark it as spam.
Forward it to all your friends to see if it's legitimate.
Click on the links in the email to investigate further.
questions.ex: This is likely a phishing scam. Sharing personal or financial information is risky. Deleting and marking as spam is the safest action.

questions.q: You are working on a tight deadline, and a colleague asks for your help with their urgent task. You know helping them will delay your own work. What do you do?
options: Politely explain your situation and deadline, and perhaps offer limited help if possible or suggest someone else.
Drop your work and help them completely.
Rudely refuse to help.
Promise to help but then don't.
questions.ex: Balancing collegiality with personal responsibility is important. Honest communication about your own constraints is key.

questions.q: You witness a shopkeeper overcharging a customer who seems unaware. What would you do?
options: Ignore it as it's not your business.
Quietly inform the customer about the overcharge after they have paid.
Politely point out the discrepancy to the shopkeeper or the customer before payment.
Create a scene and accuse the shopkeeper loudly.
questions.ex: Intervening politely and constructively can help the unaware customer without causing unnecessary conflict. Informing before payment is most effective.

questions.q: You are given a task that you have no experience with. How do you approach it?
options: Refuse the task immediately stating lack of experience.
Accept the task and try to learn, seeking guidance and resources as needed.
Accept the task and try to do it without asking for any help, hoping for the best.
Delegate the task to someone else if possible.
questions.ex: Taking on new challenges is an opportunity for growth. A proactive approach involves learning and seeking help when necessary.

questions.q: You are in a cinema, and the person behind you is constantly talking on their phone loudly. What is your reaction?
options: Suffer in silence.
Turn around and politely ask them to lower their voice or take the call outside.
Shout at them to be quiet.
Complain to the cinema staff.
questions.ex: A polite request is usually the best first step. If that doesn't work, involving staff is a reasonable escalation.

questions.q: You find out that a rumor is being spread about you at your workplace. What do you do?
options: Confront the person you suspect started the rumor aggressively.
Ignore the rumor and hope it goes away.
Try to find the source and address the rumor calmly and factually, or report to HR if it's serious.
Start a counter-rumor about someone else.
questions.ex: Addressing rumors directly and calmly is often effective. If the rumor is damaging or constitutes harassment, involving HR is appropriate.

questions.q: You are the last person to leave the office and notice that a computer is still switched on. What would you do?
options: Leave it on, as it's not your responsibility.
Switch it off to save energy.
Inform the security guard.
Try to find out whose computer it is and inform them the next day.
questions.ex: Taking small steps like switching off unused equipment contributes to energy saving and is a responsible action.

questions.q: You are on a diet, and your friends insist you eat a high-calorie dessert at a party. How do you handle this?
options: Eat it to not offend your friends.
Politely decline, explaining you are on a diet or simply say you are full.
Lecture your friends about healthy eating.
Eat a small portion and then feel guilty.
questions.ex: It's important to stick to personal goals. A polite refusal is perfectly acceptable and usually respected.

questions.q: You see a child lost and crying in a crowded market. What would be your first action?
options: Ignore the child and continue with your shopping.
Approach the child, try to comfort them, and ask for their parents' names or contact.
Take the child to the nearest police officer or information desk.
Both b and c are appropriate steps, with c being the ultimate goal.
questions.ex: Comforting the child and trying to get information is a good first step. Then, taking them to an authority figure (police/information desk) is crucial for their safety and reunion with parents.

questions.q: Your neighbor plays loud music late at night frequently, disturbing your sleep. What should you do?
options: Start playing your music even louder in retaliation.
Call the police immediately every time it happens.
Speak to your neighbor politely about the issue first, and if it persists, consider other options.
Suffer in silence and buy earplugs.
questions.ex: Direct and polite communication is often the best first approach to resolving neighborly disputes. Escalation should be a later step if needed.

questions.q: You are in a group discussion, and another participant makes a point you strongly disagree with. How do you respond?
options: Interrupt them and tell them they are wrong.
Wait for them to finish, then respectfully state your counter-argument with reasons.
Stay silent to avoid conflict.
Dismiss their point sarcastically.
questions.ex: Respectful disagreement and reasoned arguments are key to productive discussions. Listening before responding is important.

questions.q: You are given a task with unclear instructions by your superior. What do you do?
options: Proceed with the task based on your assumptions.
Ask your superior for clarification before starting.
Complain to your colleagues about the unclear instructions.
Ignore the task until clearer instructions are given.
questions.ex: Seeking clarification ensures you understand the task correctly and can deliver what is expected, avoiding mistakes and wasted effort.

questions.q: You are walking down the street and see a person collapse. You are trained in CPR. What do you do?
options: Walk away quickly as you don't want to get involved.
Check for responsiveness, call for emergency medical help immediately, then begin CPR if needed.
Wait for someone else to help.
Start CPR immediately without checking for responsiveness or calling for help.
questions.ex: The correct emergency protocol is to ensure the scene is safe, check for responsiveness, call for professional help, and then administer aid like CPR if trained and necessary.

questions.q: You have made a significant mistake at work that could have serious consequences. What is your course of action?
options: Try to cover up the mistake.
Inform your supervisor about the mistake immediately and suggest possible solutions.
Blame a colleague for the mistake.
Hope no one notices the mistake.
questions.ex: Taking ownership of mistakes, reporting them promptly, and contributing to solutions demonstrates responsibility and integrity.

questions.q: You are in a remote area and your car breaks down. You have no mobile network. What do you do?
options: Panic and stay in the car indefinitely.
Start walking in a random direction hoping to find help.
Stay with your car for safety, try to make it visible, and wait for a passerby or assess if you can walk to a known landmark if visible.
Abandon the car and try to hitchhike immediately.
questions.ex: Staying with the vehicle is generally safer. Making it visible (e.g., hazard lights, hood up) increases chances of being seen. If help is unlikely, carefully planned walking to a known point might be considered.

questions.q: A new colleague joins your team, and they seem shy and are having trouble integrating. What would you do?
options: Ignore them, as it's their responsibility to fit in.
Make an effort to welcome them, introduce them to others, and include them in team activities.
Talk about them with other colleagues.
Wait for them to approach you first.
questions.ex: Being welcoming and inclusive helps new team members feel comfortable and integrate more quickly, benefiting the whole team.

questions.q: You are asked to give a presentation on short notice on a topic you are not fully prepared for. What do you do?
options: Refuse to give the presentation.
Accept, quickly gather key information, focus on what you know, and be honest about areas you are less familiar with if asked.
Try to make up information during the presentation.
Call in sick to avoid the presentation.
questions.ex: Making the best of the situation by preparing as much as possible and being honest is a professional approach.

questions.q: You are using a public restroom and find it in an untidy state. What is your reaction?
options: Make it even messier.
Use it and leave it as it is.
Try to tidy it up a bit if possible (e.g., flush, dispose of paper towels properly) or inform the cleaning staff if available.
Complain loudly to everyone around.
questions.ex: Civic sense involves leaving public facilities in a reasonable state or reporting issues to the responsible staff.

questions.q: You are offered a promotion that requires relocating to a city you dislike. What factors would you consider most?
options: Accept immediately for career growth without considering personal preferences.
Decline immediately because you dislike the city.
Weigh the career benefits against personal and family impact, and then make an informed decision.
Ask for more money to compensate for the relocation to a disliked city.
questions.ex: Major life decisions like relocation require a balanced consideration of professional opportunities and personal well-being.

questions.q: A man walks 5 km towards South and then turns to the right. After walking 3 km he turns to the left and walks 5 km. Now in which direction is he from the starting place?
options: West
South
North-East
South-West
questions.ex: He first walks South. Turning right means he walks West. Then turning left means he walks South again. So, his final position is South-West of his starting point.

questions.q: Rahul put his timepiece on the table in such a way that at 6 P.M. hour hand points to North. In which direction the minute hand will point at 9.15 P.M.?
options: South-East
South
North
West
questions.ex: At 6 P.M., hour hand is at 6 and points North. So, 12 is South, 3 is West, 9 is East. At 9.15 P.M., minute hand is at 3, which is West.

questions.q: A man walks 1 km towards East and then he turns to South and walks 5 km. Again he turns to East and walks 2 km, after this he turns to North and walks 9 km. Now, how far is he from his starting point?
options: 3 km
4 km
5 km
7 km
questions.ex: Total distance East = 1 + 2 = 3 km. Total distance North = 9 - 5 = 4 km. Using Pythagoras theorem, distance = sqrt(3^2 + 4^2) = sqrt(9 + 16) = sqrt(25) = 5 km.

questions.q: If South-East becomes North, North-East becomes West and so on. What will West become?
options: North-East
North-West
South-East
South-West
questions.ex: The directions are rotating clockwise by 135 degrees. South-East to North is 135 degrees clockwise. So, West will become South-East (West + 135 degrees clockwise).

questions.q: A man is facing North-West. He turns 90 degrees in the clockwise direction, then 180 degrees in the anti-clockwise direction and then another 90 degrees in the same direction. Which direction is he facing now?
options: South
South-West
West
South-East
questions.ex: Starts North-West. +90 (CW) -> North-East. -180 (ACW) -> South-West. -90 (ACW) -> South-East.

questions.q: Kunal walks 10 km towards North. From there, he walks 6 km towards South. Then, he walks 3 km towards East. How far and in which direction is he with reference to his starting point?
options: 5 km West
5 km North-East
7 km East
7 km West
questions.ex: Net North movement = 10 - 6 = 4 km North. East movement = 3 km East. Distance = sqrt(4^2 + 3^2) = 5 km. Direction is North-East.

questions.q: One morning Udai and Vishal were talking to each other face to face at a crossing. If Vishal's shadow was exactly to the left of Udai, which direction was Udai facing?
options: East
West
North
South
questions.ex: In the morning, sun is in the East, so shadow is towards West. If Vishal's shadow is to Udai's left, and they are face to face, Udai must be facing North (so his left is West).

questions.q: Y is in the East of X which is in the North of Z. If P is in the South of Z, then in which direction of Y, is P?
options: North
South
South-East
South-West
questions.ex: X is North of Z. Y is East of X. P is South of Z. So Y is North-East of Z. P is South of Z. Therefore, P is South-West of Y.

questions.q: If A x B means A is to the South of B; A + B means A is to the North of B; A % B means A is to the East of B; A - B means A is to the West of B; then in P % Q + R - S, S is in which direction with respect to Q?
options: South-West
South-East
North-East
North-West
questions.ex: P % Q -> P is East of Q. Q + R -> Q is North of R (or R is South of Q). R - S -> R is West of S (or S is East of R). So Q is North of R, and S is East of R. Thus S is South-East of Q.

questions.q: A child is looking for his father. He went 90 metres in the East before turning to his right. He went 20 metres before turning to his right again to look for his father at his uncle's place 30 metres from this point. His father was not there. From there, he went 100 metres to his North before meeting his father in a street. How far did the son meet his father from the starting point?
options: 80 metres
100 metres
140 metres
260 metres
questions.ex: East 90m. Right (South) 20m. Right (West) 30m. North 100m. Net East = 90-30 = 60m. Net North = 100-20 = 80m. Distance = sqrt(60^2 + 80^2) = sqrt(3600+6400) = sqrt(10000) = 100 metres.

questions.q: Starting from a point P, Sachin walked 20 metres towards South. He turned left and walked 30 metres. He then turned left and walked 20 metres. He again turned left and walked 40 metres and reached a point Q. How far and in which direction is the point Q from the point P?
options: 20 metres West
10 metres East
10 metres West
10 metres North
questions.ex: South 20m. Left (East) 30m. Left (North) 20m. Left (West) 40m. The South and North movements cancel out. Net West movement = 40 - 30 = 10m West from the point after first East turn. So Q is 10m West of P.

questions.q: A river flows West to East and on the way turns left and goes in a semi-circle round a hillock, and then turns left at right angles. In which direction is the river finally flowing?
options: West
East
North
South
questions.ex: Flows West to East. Turns left (North). Semi-circle (ends up going South). Turns left at right angles (East). Wait, if it goes North, then semi-circle means it will be going South. Then turns left (East). Let's re-evaluate. West to East. Turns Left (North). Semi-circle means it will be flowing South. Then turns left (East). This seems wrong. If it turns left from East, it goes North. A semi-circle would mean it ends up going South. Then a left turn from South is East. The question might imply the semi-circle is around a hillock on its left. If flowing East, turns left (North). Semi-circle (hillock on left) means it curves right, ending South. Then turns left (East). If semi-circle (hillock on right) means it curves left, ending South. Then turns left (East). Let's assume standard turn. East -> Left (North) -> Semi-circle (ends South) -> Left (East). This is confusing. Let's assume the semi-circle is such that it continues the general direction change. East -> Left (North). Semi-circle continues this turn, so it goes West, then South. Then turns left (East). This is also not standard. Let's assume the semi-circle is a U-turn. East -> Left (North). U-turn -> South. Left turn from South -> East. The most standard interpretation: Flows East. Turns Left (North). Semi-circle (implies it will be flowing South after the curve). Turns Left from South (East). This is not among options. Let's re-read. 'goes in a semi-circle round a hillock'. If flowing North, and hillock is on the left, it turns right, ending South. If hillock on right, turns left, ending South. So it flows South. Then turns left at right angles. From South, left is East. This is still not matching options. Let's assume the semi-circle means it turns 180 degrees. East -> Left (North) -> 180 degree turn (South) -> Left (East). This is not an option. What if 'turns left and goes in a semi-circle' means it makes a left turn and then completes a semi-circle. East -> Left (North). Then a semi-circle from North would end up South. Then turns left (East). This is not working. Let's try another interpretation. River flows West to East. On the way turns left (now flowing North). Goes in a semi-circle round a hillock (meaning it curves, let's say it ends up flowing West). Then turns left at right angles (now flowing South). This is an option.

questions.q: I am facing East. I turn 100 degrees in the clockwise direction and then 145 degrees in the anti-clockwise direction. Which direction am I facing now?
options: East
North-East
North
South-West
questions.ex: Facing East. +100 deg CW from East is South-East (East is 0, South is 90, so 100 is past South). Then -145 deg ACW. Net change = 100 CW - 145 ACW = -45 ACW. So, 45 deg ACW from East is North-East.

questions.q: A man is facing South. He turns 135 degrees in the anti-clockwise direction and then 180 degrees in the clockwise direction. Which direction is he facing now?
options: North-East
North-West
South-East
South-West
questions.ex: Facing South. -135 deg ACW from South (180 deg) is 180 - 135 = 45 deg, which is North-East. Then +180 deg CW from North-East is South-West.

questions.q: Town D is 13 km towards the East of town A. A bus starts from town A, travels 8 km towards West and takes a right turn. After taking the right turn, it travels 5 km and reaches town B. From town B the bus takes a right turn again, travels 21 km and stops. How far and towards which direction must the bus travel to reach town D?
options: 13 km towards South
5 km towards West
21 km towards South
5 km towards South
