questions.ex: A is origin (0,0). D is (13,0). Bus from A: West 8km -> (-8,0). Right turn (North) 5km -> (-8,5) this is B. From B, right turn (East) 21km -> (-8+21, 5) = (13,5). This is current stop. D is at (13,0). So bus must travel 5km South to reach D.

questions.q: A person starts from point A, walks 10m in the South direction. He then takes a left turn and walks 7m. He again takes a left turn and walks 15m. He then takes a left turn and walks 7m. He takes a final left turn and walks 5m to reach point B. How far is point B from point A?
options: 0m (At point A)
5m
Cannot be determined
questions.ex: South 10m. Left (East) 7m. Left (North) 15m. Left (West) 7m. Left (South) 5m. Net South = 10 - 15 + 5 = 0. Net East = 7 - 7 = 0. So he is back at point A.

questions.q: Ram starts from his house and walks 4 km North, then 3 km West, then 8 km South. How many kilometers will he have to walk to reach his house straight?
options: 3 km
4 km
5 km
6 km
questions.ex: North 4km. West 3km. South 8km. Net South = 8-4 = 4km. Net West = 3km. Distance to house = sqrt(4^2 + 3^2) = sqrt(16+9) = sqrt(25) = 5km.

questions.q: If North is called North-West, West is called South-West, South is called South-East, what will East be called?
options: North-East
North-West
South-East
None of these
questions.ex: Each direction is shifting 45 degrees anti-clockwise. North -> North-West. West -> South-West. South -> South-East. So East will become North-East.

questions.q: A watch reads 4:30. If the minute hand points East, in what direction will the hour hand point?
options: North
North-West
North-East
South-East
questions.ex: At 4:30, minute hand is at 6. If 6 points East, then 12 is West, 3 is North, 9 is South. Hour hand is between 4 and 5. 4 is slightly North of North-East (if 3 is North). So hour hand is North-East.

questions.q: Mohan starts from point A and walks 1 km towards south, turns left and walks 1 km. Then he turns left again and walks 1 km. Now he is facing:?
options: East
West
North
South-West
questions.ex: South 1km. Turns left (East) 1km. Turns left (North) 1km. He is now facing North.

questions.q: Suresh walks 20m North. Then he turns right and walks 30m. Then he turns right and walks 35m. Then he turns left and walks 15m. Then he again turns left and walks 15m. In which direction and how many metres is he from the starting position?
options: 15m West
30m East
30m West
45m East
questions.ex: North 20m. Right (East) 30m. Right (South) 35m. Left (East) 15m. Left (North) 15m. Net North = 20 - 35 + 15 = 0. Net East = 30 + 15 = 45m. So, 45m East.

questions.q: A man is performing yoga with his head down and legs up. His face is towards the West. In which direction will his left hand be?
options: North
South
East
West
questions.ex: If head is down and face is West, his normal orientation would have his back to the West. So he is effectively facing East. If facing East, left hand is North.

questions.q: Going 50 m to the South of her house, Radhika turns left and goes another 20 m. Then, turning to the North, she goes 30 m and then starts walking to her house. In which direction is she walking now?
options: North-West
North
South-East
East
questions.ex: House (0,0). South 50m -> (0,-50). Left (East) 20m -> (20,-50). North 30m -> (20, -20). Now walking to house (0,0). She needs to go West and North. So North-West.

questions.q: Village Q is to the North of village P. Village R is to the East of village Q. Village S is to the Left of village P. In which direction is village S with respect to village R?
options: West
South-West
South
North-West
questions.ex: P is origin. Q is North of P. R is East of Q. S is Left (West) of P. So S is West of P, Q is North of P, R is North-East of P. S is South-West of R.

questions.q: A person walks 4 km towards west, then turns to his right to travel 9 km. He turns towards east and travels 12 km. Finally, he travels 3 km towards south. How far is he from the initial position?
options: 10 km
12 km
8 km
15 km
questions.ex: West 4km. Right (North) 9km. East 12km. South 3km. Net East = 12-4 = 8km. Net North = 9-3 = 6km. Distance = sqrt(8^2 + 6^2) = sqrt(64+36) = sqrt(100) = 10km.

questions.q: One evening, two friends Riya and Priya were talking to each other with their backs towards each other. If Riya's shadow was exactly to her left hand side, which direction was Priya facing?
options: North
South
East
West
questions.ex: Evening, sun is in West, shadow is East. Riya's shadow is to her left. If shadow (East) is left, Riya is facing North. Priya has her back to Riya, so Priya is facing South.

questions.q: A clock is so placed that at 12 noon its minute hand points towards North-East. In which direction does its hour hand point at 1.30 PM?
options: North
South
East
West
questions.ex: At 12 noon, minute hand (at 12) points NE. So 12 is NE. At 1.30 PM, hour hand is between 1 and 2. If 12 is NE, 3 is SE, 6 is SW, 9 is NW. 1 is slightly clockwise from NE. 1.30 hour hand is halfway between 1 and 2. This means it is pointing East.

questions.q: Roy walks 2 km to East, then turns North-West and walks 3 km. Then he turns South and walks 5 km. Then he turns West and walks 2 km. Finally, he turns North and walks 6 km. In which direction is he from the starting point?
options: South-West
South-East
North-West
North-East
questions.ex: This requires careful vector addition or coordinate geometry. East 2km. NW 3km (approx -2.12 West, +2.12 North). South 5km. West 2km. North 6km. It's complex to calculate exact final bearing without precise angles for NW. Assuming NW is 45 deg. East 2. NW 3 (-2.12E, 2.12N). South 5. West 2. North 6. Net East/West: 2 - 2.12 - 2 = -2.12 (West). Net North/South: 2.12 - 5 + 6 = 3.12 (North). So, North-West.

questions.q: From her home, Prerna wishes to go to school. From home, she goes towards North and then turns left and then turns right, and finally she turns left and reaches school. In which direction her school is situated with respect to her home?
options: North-East
North-West
South-East
South-West
questions.ex: Home. North. Left (West). Right (North). Left (West). School is to the North-West of home.

questions.q: A man walks 6 km towards East, then 5 km towards South, then 6 km towards West and then 10 km towards North. How far is he from the starting point?
options: 5 km
6 km
10 km
12 km
questions.ex: East 6km. South 5km. West 6km. North 10km. East and West movements cancel out. Net North movement = 10 - 5 = 5km. So he is 5km North from starting point.

questions.q: What is the value of x? Statements: (1) x + y = 5 (2) 2x - y = 7
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: From (1), we cannot find x. From (2), we cannot find x. Adding (1) and (2), 3x = 12, so x = 4. Thus, both are needed.

questions.q: Is an integer n divisible by 3? Statements: (1) n is the sum of three consecutive integers. (2) n is the sum of two consecutive integers.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) Let the integers be k, k+1, k+2. Sum = 3k+3 = 3(k+1), which is divisible by 3. Sufficient. (2) Let integers be k, k+1. Sum = 2k+1. This is not always divisible by 3 (e.g., k=1, sum=3; k=2, sum=5). Not sufficient.

questions.q: What is the area of triangle ABC? Statements: (1) AB = 5 cm, BC = 7 cm. (2) Angle ABC = 90 degrees.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) Two sides are not enough to find the area. (2) Knowing one angle is 90 degrees is not enough without side lengths. Together, Area = 0.5 * AB * BC = 0.5 * 5 * 7 = 17.5 sq cm. Both needed.

questions.q: Is x > y? Statements: (1) x - z > y - z (2) x/z > y/z
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) x - z > y - z implies x > y. Sufficient. (2) x/z > y/z implies x > y only if z > 0. If z < 0, then x < y. If z = 0, it's undefined. Not sufficient.

questions.q: What is the speed of the train? Statements: (1) The train crosses a pole in 10 seconds. (2) The train crosses a platform of length 200m in 30 seconds.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Let length of train be L and speed be S. (1) L/S = 10. (2) (L+200)/S = 30. From (1), L=10S. Substitute in (2): (10S+200)/S = 30 => 10S+200 = 30S => 20S = 200 => S = 10 m/s. Both needed.

questions.q: Is a > b? Statements: (1) a^2 > b^2 (2) a - c > b - c, where c < 0.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If a=-3, b=2, then a^2=9 > b^2=4, but a < b. Not sufficient. (2) a - c > b - c implies a > b, regardless of c's value. Sufficient.

questions.q: What is the age of Ram? Statements: (1) Ram is 5 years older than Shyam. (2) Shyam is 10 years old.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) R = S + 5. Cannot find R. (2) S = 10. Cannot find R. Together, R = 10 + 5 = 15. Both needed.

questions.q: Is the product xy positive? Statements: (1) x > 0 (2) y < 0
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If x > 0, xy can be positive (if y>0) or negative (if y<0). Not sufficient. (2) If y < 0, xy can be positive (if x<0) or negative (if x>0). Not sufficient. Together, x>0 and y<0 means xy is negative. Sufficient to answer the question (No, it's not positive).

questions.q: What is the perimeter of a rectangle? Statements: (1) The length of the rectangle is 10 cm. (2) The width of the rectangle is 5 cm.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Perimeter P = 2(L+W). (1) L=10. Cannot find P. (2) W=5. Cannot find P. Together, P = 2(10+5) = 30 cm. Both needed.

questions.q: Is x an even integer? Statements: (1) x is a prime number. (2) x + 1 is an even integer.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If x is prime, x can be 2 (even) or 3, 5, 7... (odd). Not sufficient. (2) If x+1 is even, then x must be odd. Sufficient to answer (No, x is not even).

questions.q: What is the average of a, b, and c? Statements: (1) a + b = 10 (2) b + c = 20
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Average = (a+b+c)/3. (1) a+b=10. Cannot find average. (2) b+c=20. Cannot find average. Together, we have a+b=10 and b+c=20. We still cannot find a+b+c uniquely. Not sufficient.

questions.q: Is triangle PQR equilateral? Statements: (1) PQ = QR (2) Angle PQR = 60 degrees.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) PQ=QR means it's isosceles. Not necessarily equilateral. (2) One angle is 60. Not necessarily equilateral. Together, if PQ=QR and angle PQR=60, then angles QPR and QRP are equal and sum to 120, so each is 60. Thus, equilateral. Both needed.

questions.q: What is the value of 2x + 3y? Statements: (1) x = 5 (2) y = x - 2
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) x=5. We don't know y. Not sufficient. (2) y = x-2. We don't know x or y. Not sufficient. Together, x=5, so y=5-2=3. Then 2x+3y = 2(5)+3(3) = 10+9 = 19. Both needed.

questions.q: Is x an integer? Statements: (1) 3x is an integer. (2) x/3 is an integer.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If 3x is an integer, x could be 1/3 (3x=1) or x could be 1 (3x=3). Not sufficient. (2) If x/3 is an integer k, then x = 3k, which means x is an integer (multiple of 3). Sufficient.

questions.q: How many children does M have? Statements: (1) H is the only daughter of X who is wife of M. (2) K and J are brothers of M.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) H is the only daughter of X (M's wife). This means M has at least one child (H), and H is the only female child. M could have sons. Not sufficient. (2) K and J are brothers of M. This gives no information about M's children. Not sufficient. Together, still not sufficient to determine the total number of children.

questions.q: What is the selling price of the article? Statements: (1) The cost price of the article is $50. (2) The profit made was 20%.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) CP = $50. SP unknown. (2) Profit = 20%. SP = CP * (1 + Profit%). We don't know CP. Together, SP = 50 * (1 + 0.20) = 50 * 1.2 = $60. Both needed.

questions.q: Is x = y? Statements: (1) x^2 - y^2 = 0 (2) x - y = 0
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) x^2 - y^2 = 0 => (x-y)(x+y)=0. So x=y or x=-y. Not sufficient. (2) x-y=0 => x=y. Sufficient.

questions.q: What is the two-digit number? Statements: (1) The sum of the digits is 7. (2) The digit in the tens place is 3 more than the digit in the units place.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Let the number be 10t + u. (1) t+u=7. Possible numbers: 16, 25, 34, 43, 52, 61, 70. Not sufficient. (2) t = u+3. Possible numbers: 30, 41, 52, 63, 74, 85, 96. Not sufficient. Together: u+3+u=7 => 2u=4 => u=2. Then t=5. Number is 52. Both needed.

questions.q: Is line L parallel to line M? Statements: (1) Line L and line M are both perpendicular to line N. (2) Line L and line M do not intersect.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If two lines are perpendicular to the same line, they are parallel to each other. Sufficient. (2) If two distinct lines in a plane do not intersect, they are parallel. Sufficient. (Assuming lines are in the same plane, which is standard for such geometry questions unless specified otherwise like skew lines in 3D).

questions.q: What is the value of |x|? Statements: (1) x = -5 (2) x^2 = 25
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If x=-5, then |x|=|-5|=5. Sufficient. (2) If x^2=25, then x=5 or x=-5. In both cases, |x|=5. Sufficient.

questions.q: Is integer P prime? Statements: (1) P is an odd integer. (2) 2 < P < 10.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) P is odd. P could be 3 (prime) or 9 (not prime). Not sufficient. (2) 2 < P < 10. P could be 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. Primes are 3, 5, 7. Non-primes are 4, 6, 8, 9. Not sufficient. Together: P is odd and 2 < P < 10. So P can be 3, 5, 7, 9. 3,5,7 are prime, 9 is not. Still not sufficient.

questions.q: What is the length of diagonal of a square? Statements: (1) The area of the square is 36 sq cm. (2) The perimeter of the square is 24 cm.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Let side be 's'. Diagonal d = s*sqrt(2). (1) Area = s^2 = 36 => s=6. d = 6*sqrt(2). Sufficient. (2) Perimeter = 4s = 24 => s=6. d = 6*sqrt(2). Sufficient.

questions.q: Is x > 0? Statements: (1) x + 5 > 0 (2) x - 5 > 0
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) x + 5 > 0 => x > -5. x could be -1 (not >0) or 1 (>0). Not sufficient. (2) x - 5 > 0 => x > 5. If x > 5, then x is definitely > 0. Sufficient.

questions.q: What is the sum of two numbers? Statements: (1) The product of the two numbers is 24. (2) The difference between the two numbers is 5.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Let numbers be a, b. (1) ab=24. (e.g., 3,8 sum 11; 4,6 sum 10). Not sufficient. (2) |a-b|=5. (e.g., 8,3 sum 11; 1,6 sum 7). Not sufficient. Together: ab=24, a-b=5 (or b-a=5). If a-b=5, a=b+5. (b+5)b=24 => b^2+5b-24=0 => (b+8)(b-3)=0. So b=3, a=8 (sum 11) or b=-8, a=-3 (sum -11). Since the sum can be 11 or -11, it's not unique. However, if we assume positive integers, then sum is 11. If the question implies unique sum, then it's not sufficient. Standard DS assumes we need a unique value. Let's check if (a+b)^2 = (a-b)^2 + 4ab = 5^2 + 4*24 = 25 + 96 = 121. So a+b = +/- 11. Not unique. Thus, statements together are NOT sufficient.

questions.q: Is y an integer? Statements: (1) y^2 is an integer. (2) sqrt(y) is an integer.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) If y^2 is an integer, y could be sqrt(2) (y^2=2) or y=2 (y^2=4). Not sufficient. (2) If sqrt(y) is an integer k, then y = k^2. Since k is an integer, k^2 (which is y) must be an integer. Sufficient.

questions.q: What is the percentage profit? Statements: (1) Cost Price is $200. (2) Selling Price is $240.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Profit % = ((SP-CP)/CP)*100. (1) CP=200. SP unknown. (2) SP=240. CP unknown. Together: Profit % = ((240-200)/200)*100 = (40/200)*100 = 20%. Both needed.

questions.q: Is x/y an integer? Statements: (1) x is an integer. (2) y is an integer.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: (1) x is integer. y could be non-integer or integer. If x=2, y=0.5, x/y=4 (integer). If x=2, y=3, x/y not integer. Not sufficient. (2) y is integer. x could be non-integer or integer. If x=2.5, y=1, x/y not integer. If x=4, y=2, x/y=2 (integer). Not sufficient. Together: x and y are integers. If x=3, y=2, x/y not integer. If x=4, y=2, x/y is integer. Not sufficient (y cannot be 0).

questions.q: What is the value of a if a and b are positive integers? Statements: (1) a/b = 3.5 (2) b = 2
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.

questions.ex: (1) a/b = 3.5 = 7/2. Since a,b are positive integers, b could be 2 (a=7), or b could be 4 (a=14), etc. Not sufficient. (2) b=2. 'a' is unknown. Not sufficient. Together: a/2 = 3.5 => a = 7. Both needed.

questions.q: Is the number N divisible by 6? Statements: (1) N is divisible by 2. (2) N is divisible by 3.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.

EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: A number is divisible by 6 if it is divisible by both 2 and 3. (1) N divisible by 2 (e.g., 2, 4, 6, 8). Not sufficient. (2) N divisible by 3 (e.g., 3, 6, 9). Not sufficient. Together: N is divisible by 2 and 3, so N is divisible by 6. Both needed.

questions.q: What is the time taken by a boat to travel 60 km upstream? Statements: (1) The speed of the boat in still water is 15 km/hr. (2) The speed of the stream is 5 km/hr.
options: Statement (1) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (2) alone is not sufficient.
Statement (2) ALONE is sufficient, but statement (1) alone is not sufficient.
BOTH statements TOGETHER are sufficient, but NEITHER statement ALONE is sufficient.
EACH statement ALONE is sufficient.
Statements (1) and (2) TOGETHER are NOT sufficient.
questions.ex: Upstream speed = Speed of boat - Speed of stream. Time = Distance / Speed. (1) Boat speed = 15. Stream speed unknown. (2) Stream speed = 5. Boat speed unknown. Together: Upstream speed = 15 - 5 = 10 km/hr. Time = 60/10 = 6 hours. Both needed.

questions.q: Which word does not belong with the others?
options: Eagle
Sparrow
Ostrich
Penguin
questions.ex: Eagle and Sparrow can fly. Ostrich and Penguin are flightless birds. However, Ostrich is typically grouped with large flightless birds, while Eagle and Sparrow are common flying birds. Penguin is also flightless but adapted to aquatic life. The most distinct is Ostrich if considering commonality of flight. Another perspective: Eagle, Sparrow, Ostrich are birds. Penguin is also a bird. Let's re-evaluate. Eagle, Sparrow can fly. Ostrich and Penguin cannot. Among the flightless, Ostrich is known for running, Penguin for swimming. The common grouping is often flying vs. non-flying. If we must pick one, perhaps Ostrich is the largest. Or, Eagle is a bird of prey. Let's assume the primary distinction is flight. Eagle and Sparrow fly. Ostrich and Penguin do not. This doesn't isolate one. Let's consider habitat. Eagle, Sparrow (varied, often land/trees). Ostrich (grasslands). Penguin (cold, aquatic/coastal). This also doesn't clearly isolate one. Let's consider common perception. Eagle, Sparrow are common flying birds. Ostrich is a very large flightless bird. Penguin is a flightless bird associated with cold regions. The odd one out is often based on a prominent feature. Ostrich is the largest bird. Eagle is a predator. Sparrow is small. Penguin lives in cold climates. The intended answer is likely Ostrich due to its unique size and being a prominent example of a flightless bird distinct from smaller birds or aquatic birds.

questions.q: Look at this series: 7, 10, 8, 11, 9, 12, ... What number should come next?
